trial_identification.studytitle: Cognitive Impairment Following Sedation for Colonoscopy With Propofol, Midazolam and Fentanyl Combinations
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Cognitive Impairment Following Sedation for Colonoscopy With Propofol, Midazolam and Fentanyl Combinations

interventions.interventions:
Treatment: drugs - Propofol, midazolam, fentanyl
Active Comparator: 1 - These patients will only receive intravenous propofol which will be titrated to an OAA/S score of 3. They will not receive fentanyl, midazolam or any other drugs
Active Comparator: 2 - These patients will receive propofol plus midazolam and/or fentanyl. Midazolam and fentanyl will be given in fixed doses first and propofol will be titrated to effect. All drugs will be given intravenously.
Treatment: drugs: Propofol, midazolam, fentanyl All drugs administered in doses according to anaesthetists' discretion during sedation for colonoscopy

primaryOutcome.outcome: Cognitive impairment at hospital discharge after elective outpatient colonoscopy

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Dreaming during sedation, intraoperative operating conditions and complications, satisfaction with care

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: - Aged 18 years or older presenting for elective outpatient colonoscopy following full bowel preparation
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
- No cognitive impairment
- Adequate English language comprehension
- Not combined with other procedures

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Our hypothesis is that adding midazolam and/or fentanyl to propofol sedation for elective outpatient colonoscopy increases cognitive impairment at hospital discharge without improving intraoperative conditions or reducing intraoperative side-effects.
200 healthy patients aged 18 years or older will be randomised to receive propofol or propofol plus midazolam and/or fentanyl. Cognitive impairment will be tested at hospital discharge using Cogstate computerised testing software.
